Context dependent expressions

Source: R/context.R
context.Rd

These functions return information about the "current" group or "current" variable, so only work inside specific contexts like summarise() and mutate()

  • n() gives the current group size.

  • cur_data() gives the current data for the current group (exclusing grouping variables)

  • cur_group() gives the group keys, a tibble with one row and one column for each grouping variable.

  • cur_group_id() gives a unique numeric identifier for the current group.

  • cur_column() gives the name of the current column (in across() only).

See group_data() for equivalent functions that return values for all groups.

n()

cur_data()

cur_group()

cur_group_id()

cur_group_rows()

cur_column()

data.table

If you're familiar with data.table:

  • cur_data() <-> .SD

  • cur_group_id() <-> .GRP

  • cur_group() <-> .BY

  • cur_group_rows() <-> .I

Examples

df <- tibble(
  g = sample(rep(letters[1:3], 1:3)),
  x = runif(6),
  y = runif(6)
)
gf <- df %>% group_by(g)

gf %>% summarise(n = n())
#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 2
#>   g         n
#>   <chr> <int>
#> 1 a         1
#> 2 b         2
#> 3 c         3

gf %>% mutate(id = cur_group_id())
#> # A tibble: 6 x 4
#> # Groups:   g [3]
#>   g         x      y    id
#>   <chr> <dbl>  <dbl> <int>
#> 1 b     0.728 0.0384     2
#> 2 c     0.873 0.334      3
#> 3 c     0.382 0.749      3
#> 4 b     0.893 0.913      2
#> 5 c     0.844 0.204      3
#> 6 a     0.730 0.472      1
gf %>% summarise(row = cur_group_rows())
#> `summarise()` regrouping output by 'g' (override with `.groups` argument)
#> # A tibble: 6 x 2
#> # Groups:   g [3]
#>   g       row
#>   <chr> <int>
#> 1 a         6
#> 2 b         1
#> 3 b         4
#> 4 c         2
#> 5 c         3
#> 6 c         5
gf %>% summarise(data = list(cur_group()))
#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 2
#>   g     data            
#>   <chr> <list>          
#> 1 a     <tibble [1 × 1]>
#> 2 b     <tibble [1 × 1]>
#> 3 c     <tibble [1 × 1]>
gf %>% summarise(data = list(cur_data()))
#> `summarise()` ungrouping output (override with `.groups` argument)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 2
#>   g     data            
#>   <chr> <list>          
#> 1 a     <tibble [1 × 2]>
#> 2 b     <tibble [2 × 2]>
#> 3 c     <tibble [3 × 2]>

gf %>% mutate(across(everything(), ~ paste(cur_column(), round(.x, 2))))
#> # A tibble: 6 x 3
#> # Groups:   g [3]
#>   g     x      y     
#>   <chr> <chr>  <chr> 
#> 1 b     x 0.73 y 0.04
#> 2 c     x 0.87 y 0.33
#> 3 c     x 0.38 y 0.75
#> 4 b     x 0.89 y 0.91
#> 5 c     x 0.84 y 0.2 
#> 6 a     x 0.73 y 0.47
